intro: Philippia oppositifolia, commonly known as the yellow bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Campanulaceae family, characterized by its bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, often in rocky soils. Its leaves are opposite and linear, with a bluish-green hue, and it produces vibrant yellow flowers in the spring. The plant is drought-tolerant and is often used in xeriscaping due to its low water requirements.
